I like the jacket and its fit. It is indeed not too big on you, a baggy fit on tweed coats is perfectly proper and looks good, especially because you often want to wear them as outerwear with thick wool pullovers and cardigans. Besides, even an oversized fit is standard in fashion these days, but of course on 4chan fashion is all about dimwitted "right" and "wrong".

Although being tall (or rather: not being short) helps with making a baggy fit work of course.

I'm not a fan of those particular jeans, all the less so in combination with that sweater, but jeans in general are perfectly apt to wear with tweed coats. Treating tweed coats as "formal" is pretty silly. They are of the most casual of sports coats, worn even by farmers and shit, at work, play or otherwise completely informal occasions out in the environments. I would instead even argue that having some fine fabric dress pants is much more of a thematic and visual clash with the tough tweed. They are best paired with tweed pants, corduroys, thick twill/moleskin chinos or jeans, although blue jeans (even if it's a dark blue) are an a little generic look, I prefer other colours.

last_replies.com: I had these boots (steel toe) twice over a two year span, they lasted about a year each time with heavy work use. To give an idea I was a welder/carpenter and I replaced the laces on both pairs twice after they had become completely useless. They’re a decent boot, on par with other work boots at the same price point. The sole is of medium hardness which meant they stood up well to general use and didn’t slip much in the shop, but I personally prefer soft-rubber sole for walking on ice, which is a factor where I live. They could have lasted longer had I kept changing the laces but honestly they were starting to look like crap and I’m not going to bother polishing and maintaining a cheap work boot. 7/10 good boot for the price.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: /motofunk/ muh Stolen Valor but for bikers edition?
threads.com:
>what is /funktional motocore/?
/funktional motocore/ is about riding a bike/trike/scooter and being cool about it.

/funktional/ means there's an element of purpose in the fits: something suggests a 'why' behind the ride, whether it's going to the store, carrying out a population survey of coastal amphibian species, or surviving the great drought.

/motocore/ means it's a step away from the 'standard' sources of motorcycle inspo: 50s American biker culture and 60s British rockers, which have built up their own set vocabulary of fashion that extends to the motorcycle itself as a statement piece.
Instead, /motocore/ cribs inspiration from areas like contemporary South/SE Asia, or anywhere where the motorcycle (invariably a cheap, small one) is still an agile, cheap mode of transport used for daily tasks -- just as it was in the UK when biker culture was being codified.
Not that this is more 'authentic' than the 'standard' sources; we're just tapping into a fresher vein to create a newer, less played-out vocabulary of fashion where smaller, cheaper motorcycles become statement pieces.

copied from older thread in the archive

>want something loose-fitting, practically oversized
>order it two sizes too large with no regard for how it will actually look or fit

Am I doin it rite effay bros? I really just want a big comfy sweatshirt that'll make me feel like a kid again.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Usually, yeah, if the quality is good. Yohji Yamamoto pants sizing is usually based on length rather than waist size, with the latter being adjustable with drawstrings or a belt, while length is fixed and cannot be adjusted outside of cuffing - which changes the silhouette - or hemming, a semi-permanent modification that could also affect the drape. I considered myself to be a size small for years because I am slim and of average height (53kg = 117lb, ~178cm = 5'11") yet I've been increasingly buying size large because the length is flattering and I prefer the oversized fit.
